Award.AwardTitle: CC-NIE Networking Infrastructure: UCI LightPath: A Dedicated Campus Science DMZ Network for Big Data Transfer

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project establishes a new Science DMZ network infrastructure with increased bandwidth (UCI LightPath) at the University of California, Irvine to address the increasing demand for bandwidth and data-transfer performance within and beyond campus. The project also implements a new 10Gbps link from campus to the High Performance Research tier of the California Research and Education Network (CalREN-HPR) to boost science data transfer and analysis. Together these improvements to the networking infrastructure significantly enhance and expedite scientific data transfer by avoiding bottlenecks and potential performance impacting devices in the data-transfer path. The project allows campus IT personnel to explore and deploy new technologies such as the Software Defined Network (SDN) and IPv6, and to collaborate with researchers to better support their research activities.

The improved Science DMZ network infrastructure directly impacts a variety of cutting-edge data intensive research efforts across campus by enabling more complex modeling and analysis of big data sets, and facilitating data exchange among collaborative research groups in the areas of Experimental Particle Physics at the Large Hadron Collider, Genomics and Bioinformatics, Hydrologic Modeling and Remote Sensing, Flow and Combustion Dynamics of Liquid Fuels, Biomolecular Simulations, Climate Modeling, and Cosmology.

This project integrates IT research and education through an organized IT work-study program in the Office of Information Technology, which provides a platform to train future network engineers and operators. The project also supports existing K-12 outreach programs by enabling the transfer of data created in the lab to the programs for use in their curricula.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An NSF Campus Cyberinfrastructure - Network Infrastructure and Engineering (CC-NIE) grant was awarded to the University of California, Irvine (UCI) to build a Dedicated Science DMZ network for big data transfer. The two-year project established a Science DMZ Network called UCI Lightpath that increased bandwidth at UCI to address the increasing demand for bandwidth and data-transfer performance within and beyond campus. UCI Lightpath has significantly improved data transfer throughput for its users, with it being up to 15 times faster in some cases. Two main contributing factors are: 1) UCI Lightpath provides fast “last mile” connectivity to labs, avoiding bottlenecks due to insufficient network infrastructure in older buildings; and 2) UCI Lightpath provides a network path that bypasses campus border firewalls. Firewalls are less friendly to applications such as large data set transfer. 

UCI Lightpath directly impacts a variety of cutting-edge data intensive research efforts across campus by enabling more complex modeling and analysis of big data sets, and facilitating data exchanges among collaborative research groups in areas such as experimental particle physics at the Large Hadron Collider, genomics and bioinformatics, hydrologic modeling and remote sensing, flow and combustion dynamics of liquid fuels, biomolecular simulations, climate modeling, and cosmology. One example is Dr. Said Elghobashi who researches flow and combustion dynamics of liquid fuels and performs massive parallel numerical simulations on a remote facility: Blue Waters Supercomputer at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA) at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Such simulations produce extremely large datasets that need to be post-processed either on local machines or via remote visualization software. UCI LightPath improved the download speed of large datasets by 15 times and increased speed for remote visualization connections. This reduced considerably the downtimes inherent to transfer of large data, thus allowing for faster advancement in his research.

This NSF grant enabled us to accomplish the following intellectual merit and broader impacts outcomes:

  • Established direct UCI Lightpath connections (10 Gigabit/s links) to eight (soon to be 11) science and engineering buildings on campus where researchers with data-intensive projects are located. One of the buildings is the campus data center that includes two high performance computing clusters, which have over 100 users.
  • Implemented a new 10 Gigabit/s link from campus to the High Performance Research tier of the California Research and Education Network (CalREN-HPR) to boost science data transfer and analysis. This is the path through which UCI connects to national research and education networks on the Internet, such as Internet2, ESNet and international research institutions.  We have started the process of upgrading this link to 100Gigabit/s.
  • Used perfSONAR servers installed in strategic locations on UCI Lightpath and the UCI campus network to collect network performance stats and compare data transfer throughput with or without the firewall in the path. The difference is remarkable. In addition to providing researchers with immediate performance increases, UCI Lightpath deployment has highlighted the importance of upgrading our border Firewalls – this is now planned.
  • Designed a mobile perfSONAR server concept which will be plug-and-play and transportable to sites as needed. This will allow performance tests and diagnostics to be done at multiple vantage points with reduced cost and staffing. We are in the processes of developing the prototype; once it is done, it can be reproduced and can provide benefit to the network operation community.
